title: 115_hr40
content: The Act may be cited as the "Commission to Study and Develop Reparation Proposals for African-Americans Act". The Congress finds that approximately 4,000,000 Africans and their descendants were enslaved in the United States from 1619 to 1865, and that slavery was constitutionally sanctioned from 1789 to 1865. This institution deprived Africans of their rights, heritage, and the fruits of their labor, leading to ongoing systemic discrimination. Following the abolition of slavery, the United States Government continued to perpetuate discrimination against African-Americans through practices like sharecropping, Jim Crow laws, redlining, and unequal education. This historic and ongoing discrimination has led to economic, educational, and health hardships for African-Americans, including high incarceration rates and double the unemployment rate of White Americans. The purpose of this Act is to establish a commission to study and develop Reparation proposals for African-Americans due to the historic discrimination they have faced, including slavery, discrimination post-Civil War, and ongoing economic, political, educational, and social disparities. The curr_chunk discusses the negative effects of slavery and discrimination on African-Americans, the denial of slavery's inhumanity through instructional resources, Northern complicity in slavery, benefits to societal institutions, and recommendations for educating the public and implementing remedies. The curr_chunk recommends appropriate remedies based on the Commission's findings on the negative effects of slavery and discrimination on African-Americans, denial of slavery's inhumanity, Northern complicity in slavery, benefits to societal institutions, and suggestions for educating the public and implementing remedies. The curr_chunk establishes the duties of a commission to address the negative effects of slavery and discrimination on African-Americans, including educating the public and implementing remedies. The Commission is established to study and develop reparation proposals for African-Americans, with duties including identifying and compiling evidence of slavery from 1619 to 1865, such as capture, transport, and treatment of Africans. The Commission is tasked with studying and developing reparation proposals for African-Americans, including examining the sale and acquisition of Africans as chattel property, the treatment of African slaves in the colonies and the United States, and the role of Federal and State governments in supporting the institution of slavery. The Commission is studying reparation proposals for African-Americans, including discrimination in laws, public and private sectors, and the lingering effects of slavery. Recommendations will be made for educating the public and providing appropriate remedies. The Commission will recommend remedies for the lingering effects of slavery on African-Americans, including full reparations and a formal apology from the US government for human rights violations. The curr_chunk discusses how Federal laws and policies negatively affect African-Americans and how to reverse these effects, including providing compensation to descendants of enslaved Africans. The Commission will determine the form and eligibility for compensation, as well as recommend rehabilitation and restitution measures for African descendants. A report with findings and recommendations will be submitted to Congress within one year of the Commission's first meeting. SEC. 4. MEMBERSHIP. The Commission shall consist of 13 members appointed by the President, Speaker of the House, President pro tempore of the Senate, and major civil society organizations advocating for reparatory justice. Members must be qualified in African-American studies and reparatory justice. Their term of office is for life. The Commission consists of 13 members appointed for life by various entities. Vacancies do not affect the Commission's powers and are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The first meeting must be called within 120 days of enactment or 30 days after appropriations legislation. Seven members constitute a quorum, and a Chair and Vice Chair are elected from among the members for the life of the Commission. Members receive compensation unless otherwise specified. Members of the Commission are compensated at the daily rate equivalent to GS-18 pay for each day of duty, including travel time. Full-time officers or employees of the US or Members of Congress serving on the Commission do not receive additional pay. All members are reimbursed for travel and necessary expenses as authorized by law. The Commission is granted powers under Section 5. The Commission under Section 5 of the Act has the authority to hold hearings, request witnesses and documents, and invoke the aid of the court if necessary. Subcommittees and members can also take actions authorized by the Commission. Additionally, the Commission can obtain official data directly from government departments, agencies, or instrumentalities. The executive branch of the Government must provide useful information to the Commission for its duties. All departments, agencies, and instrumentalities of the executive branch shall cooperate and furnish requested information to the extent permitted by law. SEC. 6. ADMINISTRATIVE PROVISIONS. The Commission may appoint staff and fix their compensation without following certain civil service laws. The staff can be appointed without regard to competitive service rules and pay rates, with a maximum compensation limit. The Commission can also hire experts and consultants at specified rates. The Commission can procure supplies, services, and property by contract in accordance with laws and regulations. They can also enter into agreements with the Administrator of General Services for financial and administrative support services. Payment for these services will be made by reimbursement from Commission funds. The Commission can enter into contracts with various entities for research, surveys, and other necessary activities as provided in appropriations Acts. The Commission will terminate 90 days after submitting its report to Congress. $12,000,000 is authorized for carrying out the provisions of this Act.
